div.h1: Collaborative authorship: Conrad, Ford and Rolling Delta

div.div: Institute of English Studies, Jagiellonian University, Kraków, Poland
Search for other works by this author on:

Literary and Linguistic Computing, Volume 29, Issue 3, September 2014, Pages 422–431, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqu016

div.p: Jan Rybicki, David Hoover, Mike Kestemont, Collaborative authorship: Conrad, Ford and Rolling Delta, Literary and Linguistic Computing, Volume 29, Issue 3, September 2014, Pages 422–431, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqu016

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

section.p: Based on Burrows's measure of stylometric difference that uses frequencies of most frequent words, Rolling Delta is a method for revealing stylometric signals of two (or more) authors in a collaborative text. It is applied here to study the texts written jointly by Joseph Conrad and Ford Madox Ford, producing results that generally confirm the usual critical consensus on the visibility of the two author's hand. It also confirms that Ford's claims to a sizeable fragment in Nostromo are unfounded.
